climbs.name: To Tee or Not To Tee

content.description: Tricky crux low, tricky crux high.  Follow the bolts on the left side of the wall to the top, staying mostly in line with the bolts.

Climb along the Southwest arete, clipping a lone bolt just above the midway point.  Plenty of good rest stances.  This is the easiest way to access the top of the Trestle.

We have given it a PG-13 rating because the second railroad spike that needs to be slung for pro on the lower portion of the route sticks out a bit more than we would like it to, and it's what's protecting the crux move.
content.protection: Light rack, slings to attach to fixed railroad spikes. Rim anchors w/chains

content.description: Climb to the left of the bolt line on the right of the South face, staying off Iced Tee.  Follow the big blocks at the beginning  The bolts should be within reach to the climbers right.  The finish is on the right set of anchors.
No obvious crux; just lots of fun, sustained climbing.
content.protection:
2 bolts, several railroad spikes, light rack. Rim anchors w/chains.

This route can be top-roped, but you'll need to set your anchors at the middle of the wall to minimize the swing factor. Also make sure you're not going to collide with an adjacent climber.
content.location: Start at the bottom left corner of the South Face (same start as Tee Ball) and climb diagonally up to the top right corner of the face using an assortment of bolts, railroad spikes (tied off with slings), and small cams or nuts for protection.

content.description: Climb the Southeast arete and finish on the South face anchors.
content.protection: Limited, and mostly marginal gear for the first 2/3s. Micro cams may be helpful. Rim anchors w/chains

content.description: No obvious crux, but the climbing is sustained and enjoyable.
content.protection:
2 or 3 bolts, several railroad spikes, light rack. Rim anchors w/chains. Beware: There's a significant gap between bolts at the start (ground fall potential). Look for a tiny gear placement out left. Also consider clipping one of the bolts on Itchy Bitch with an extra-long sling.

This route can be top-roped, but you'll need to set your anchors at the middle of the wall to minimize the swing factor. Also make sure you're not going to collide with an adjacent climber.
content.location: Begin at the bottom right side of the South Face (at the base of The Spice is Right) and follow a diagonal path to the top left corner of the wall using an assortment of bolts, railroad spikes (tied off with slings), and small cams or nuts for protection.

content.description:
Here's a spot to practice cleaning the anchors before you're stuck at the top, being yelled the instructions on how the clean the anchors.  This is the same setup you'll find at all the anchors at the top of the trestle.

Here's some good information on how to properly clean/lower off a bolted anchor set.  Don't get hurt out here; please lower off instead of rappelling.

https://americanalpineclub.org/resources-blog/2016/3/15/5ipkouk0id07cgc3dqks4fljnsgnx6

Climb the leftmost side of the South wall, hugging the arete but not using it.

We have given it a PG-13 rating because the second railroad spike that needs to be slung for pro on the lower portion of the route sticks out a bit more than we would like it to, and it's what's protecting the crux move.
content.protection: 1 bolt, 4-5 railroad spikes, light rack.  Rim anchors w/chains

content.description:
A bit of a one-move wonder, crux 3/4 of the way up.

Keep your torso to the right of all the bolts on the right-most side of the South face.  Staying true and hugging the edge of the wall will keep it at a 5.10 level.  Do not use the arete.

This is it.  The whole reason you got into climbing. You've been training for 7 1/2 years to tackle this monster since seeing it on the front page of climbing magazine.  This route is cryptic and most likely will feel difficult for the grade at first but if you know where the holds are it opens up into a wonderful route.

Middle of the South Face.  Begin slightly to the right and then gentle traverse left after the 1st bolt.  Straight up the middle of the face from there.

“Don’t skip this climb just cause you’re scared of spiders and kitty litter—this route is a true Trestle classic!”

-Daniel “

Sweet Ass Dan

”
content.protection:
7 bolts + rim anchor w/chains

You can bring a large nut for the top to help ease the runout after the final bolt. Rim anchors w/chains
